name: VG 8020
graphics: Mode 2 : 256 x 192 with 16 colors (Hires mode)Mode 3 : 64 x 48 with 16 colors (Multi colour mode)32 sprites
sound: General Instruments AY-3-8910 Programmable Sound Generator3 channels, 8 octaves
ports: Centronics port, 2 cardridge slots, Tape-recorder connector, RGB video output, 2 joystick sockets (Atari standard), RF lead video output (PAL models)
description:
The Philips 8020 belongs to the MSX 1 family. In fact, it wasnt't built by Philips, but, as the Yashica MSX, built by Kyocera in Japan. The VG8020 comes in 3 different versions : 8020/00 are first PAL models, 8020/19 Secam models (black case) and 8020/20 PAL models with a more integrated motherboard.

There is another difference between the Secam and Pal models, one missing key. The Pal versions have one key at the right side of the right SHIFT key which is missing in the Secam version. It can be easily checked comparing pictures found here. The function of this key is for entering accents; specifically accent acute, accent grave, circumflex and tr?ma.

There's another vital difference between Secam and Pal models, the RF lead, which is missing in the Secam models.

Due to some differences in the chipset, the Philips VG-8020 was not always 100% compatible with other MSX-computers. Typing 'poke -1,170' before loading programs usually fixed the bug.

___________

Contributors: Francisco Martin, Martijn

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRONT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Odessa2020 for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SECAM MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a french Secam version. The keyboard is AZERTY and the top part of the case is black.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RIGHT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Odessa2020 for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>1</b> - Power cord<br> <b>2</b> - Reset button<br> <b>3</b> - Printer / Centronics interface<br> <b>4</b> - Tape-Recorder<br> <b>5</b> - Monitor audio/video output</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Odessa2020 for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEEP INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Video generator chipset. <br> <b>(2)</b> RGB video out DIN connector. <br> <b>(3)</b> 2 x ROM cartrige slots.<br> <b>(4)</b> Cassette recorder DIN connector with remote control. <br> <b>(5)</b> Parallel Centronics printer connector (MSX standard). <br> <b>(6)</b> Mains plug.<br> <b>(7)</b> Power supply transformer. <br> <b>(8)</b> Power regulation board. <br> <b>(9)</b> S-3527 MSX dedicated chipset. Provides MSX compatible sound generation, various input / outputs and parallel printer management. <br> <b>(10)</b> 8 x 4164 chips (64000 cells x 1 bit) holding 64 Kb RAM. <br> <b>(11-12)</b> Keyboard flat cables. <br> <b>(13)</b> Z-80 microprocessor. <br> <b>(14-15)</b> 2 x joystick connectors. <br> <b>(16)</b> RGB signals generation board. This card may differ, depending on the country where the computer was sold. This one is a french 'Peritel' (scart) version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Odessa2020 for this picture</p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the (rare!) DMX80 printer, the two floppy drive units and SDX FDD interface.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Valric-Laurène was the french importer of the Spectravideo SV-318.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... The 6800 will never win any beauty prizes. It is like the Model 'T' and the DC-3, not pretty but beautiful in function. It is simple, easy to use and maintain and does its job in the most reliable and economical way possible. What more could you want?</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-170 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first sentence of this advert is:<br> <i>The new Commodore 64  is the most powerful personal computer available to the businessman.</i><br> Which wasn't totally true, even totally false.<br><br> The picture is also totally unrealistic. Each detail sounds false.<br> The C64 never was a business system, but a perfect home computer.  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The Sinclair Phenomenon"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In U.K., at 1986 Christmas period, the 1040 STF was sold £799 + VAT for the 12" monochrome version, and £999 + VAT for the 14" colour version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> ...You will get more performances than with the IBM PC, the Apple II, TRS80 Model II or TRS80 Model III along with software support of TRSDOS or CP/M, the two most widely used operating systems. This means you, the user, can select from the largest base of business or personal software... <font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>"From 1 to 16 users"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT (1989)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This brochure was jointly published by Philips and American Interactive Media (the Philips/PolyGram joint venture that was set up to develop CD-i consumer software prior to the launch of the hardware). It was intented to give a general overview of CD-i's functionality in a consumer area. The brochure was presented to visitors of multimedia fairs and business partners at around 1989. The CD-i unit (including the remote control) that is displayed is an artist's impression of a player, it was never actually produced. The first consumer CD-i player, the CDI 910, appeared on the market in the US in October 1991.  <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source = <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a></font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"List your technical requirements, Hewlett-Packard is ready to answer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>John V. Blankenbaker designed the Kenbak-1 and marketed in the pages of Scientific American in 1971. The machine's name was taken from the middle of John's last name.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.vintage-computer.com" target="_blank">www.vintage-computer.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advertisement from a UK Sage dealer.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1ST. U.S. ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Epson QX-10 advert appeared in January 1983. It took eight pages and explained the advantages of the Valdoc system, the benefits of the CP/M operating system compatibility, and the advanced hardware concepts.   <br><br> In conclusion, it said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> <b>The most important component is you</b><br> You don't buy a computer for how "smart" it is. You buy one for how smart it makes you.<br> The Epson QX-10 was conceived, designed, engineered and built with just one thought in mind: to vastly expand your ability to see, to think, to create with a system that acts as a natural extension of the human mind.<br> The QX-10 is not a computer designed to play games, although it plays games as well as any and better than most.<br> It's a computer for people who think.<br> And who want to think better.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It has not finished to surprise you"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACCOUNTING SYSTEMS A5 AND A7</strong></font><br><blockquote>Systems A5 and A7, presented in 1974, contributing significantly to shifting the focus towards the supply Olivetti computer. These machines have the characteristics of a real computer, and hence a discontinuity from the previous accounting and billing are mainly based on mechanical technology. The new machines meet the favor of the European market and in 1975 the Swiss magazine Information, which specializes in computer and office products, a dedicated their cover.<p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.storiaolivetti.it" target="_blank">http://www.storiaolivetti.it</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Efficient companies choose professional partners"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPTEMBER 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

Panasonic  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). Yamaha mouse #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This mouse was compatible with all MSX systems. It connects to the first Joystick port.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br>  It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br>  Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>
